Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports an IAI training program consisting of five Training Institutes and Colloquia on interdisciplinary themes of global environmental change science and its applications. As part of the training institutes, Seed Grants will be provided to successful participants to actively follow-up the training events and integrate the recipients with existing IAI research teams. Participants will be natural and social scientists, policy-makers, environmental practitioners and other stakeholders. Regionally important themes will be addressed: climate & public health, governance, risk, vulnerability and adaptation, water resource management, and research analysis tools including the modeling of complex human/natural systems. Seed grants will provide an opportunity for participants to stay engaged, to build networks and to apply the training provided to real-world issues. The program will strengthen and foster multinational and multidisciplinary collaboration and may also increase the participation of small countries in IAI research programs. These activities will be developed in collaboration with other IAI science programs so that current IAI research enhances the institutes and generates cross-program interactions.

The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) was created by an international agreement concluded among representatives of American States, namely the Agreement Establishing the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research, done at Montevideo on May 13, 1992 (the IAI Agreement). The IAI Agreement created an intergovernmental organization for the purposes of coordinating and promoting scientific research related to global change. The Institute has an evolving Scientific Agenda identifying particular areas for research. Full membership in the IAI is limited to States.

The Institute is governed by an annual Conference of the Parties, and by a subsidiary Executive Council (EC). The US Government currently chairs the EC. The IAI possesses the fundamental institutional characteristics of an international organization: it was created by international agreement, is composed of States and is governed by bodies composed of representatives of States.

The US Government participates actively in the IAI. The United States played a leading role in the creation of the IAI, and has been an active participant in the IAI since its creation. Senior US Government officials have served on the Executive Council and held other responsible positions related to IAI activities. Furthermore, the IAI has been listed by the State Department and by the Office of Personnel Management as an international organization within the meaning of the Federal Employees International Organization Service Act, covered by 5 U.S.C. 3343 and 5 U.S.C. 3581.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Addressing policy relevant global change issues of the 21st century demands novel capacity building approaches, innovative policies, and integrative science to tackle these complex problems. We need a generation of young scientists, decision makers and other professionals with the skills, knowledge and tools to (1) form teams and networks and work collaboratively, (2) work across disciplines, types of expertise, and across borders, (3) apply cutting-edge problem solving approaches, (4) innovate in the face of adversity, and (5) conduct science for policy advice and decision making.

The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) has developed innovative approaches and fostered a new cadre of professionals in the Americas through its Capacity Building program. From 2011 to 2015, the IAI carried out seven training events that addressed various global change themes of societal relevance, such as climate and health, water resources in vulnerable river basins, and other socio-ecological problems. These events gathered scientists coming from various disciplines together with government officials, representative from civil society and other environmental practitioners.  An important component of the IAI training was the development of seed projects, which provided this diverse group of participants with the opportunity to develop creative projects to tackle real-world issues of global change across diverse sectors and contexts, engage in dialogue, build new collaborative networks, and expand inter- and transdisciplinary thinking,

The IAI’s approach involved three key ingredients for capacity building. First, the program’s participants were exposed to innovative research methodologies, analytical tools, and concepts. This exposure complemented their disciplinary training and expertise, and encouraged them towards more interdisciplinary framings. Second, the participants received guidance in the development of professional teams and networks to provide them with the skills to work collaboratively and across disciplinary divides. Third, the teams were coached in established approaches that fostered an problem-orientation and the convergence of science, policy and practice. The coaching provided participants with mentorship and lessons learnt from established researchers and decision makers that have been working at the interface of science-policy and in interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research.

Sixty-eight professionals from 53 institutions and 15 IAI member countries participated in the 11 seed projects. Despite its modest funding of $221,854, the seed grant impact was huge. Projects addressed climate-sensitive diseases, impacts of extreme hydro-meteorological events on agricultural systems, assessment of flood response capacities in several small countries in Latin America, climate change adaptation of cities, etc. Project results included scientific publications, presentation in international conferences, contribution to academic courses and Master’s theses, and new research proposals being prepared by the teams. In addition, there were policy outcomes, such as engagement with stakeholders and decision makers, raising awareness and sharing of scientific knowledge, production of brochures and policy briefs for policy makers, climate and health data bases and methodologies for combining climate and health information for public policy planning, and recommendations to guide science and policy in climate risk management and urban adaptation to climate change.

The IAI's innovative methods linking training seminars with seed grants was successful in meeting several goals. The program proved to be very effective in fostering dialogue and establishing communication and collaboration among scientists and professionals from different academic disciplines, from diverse communities (e.g., academia, government, civil society, private sector) and productive sectors (e.g., agriculture, health, risk reduction and disaster management) from many countries in the Americas. It provided hands on experience in the formulation of research questions that are policy relevant, it developed and strengthened skills for proposal development and management of international research grants, and communicated useful results to diverse audiences and knowledge users.

We believe that perhaps the most meaningful contribution of the training for the participants was the opportunity to experience the process of learning and practicing key elements for successful team building, co-framing of research questions, the development of transdisciplinary projects, and communicating and collaborating with stakeholders from start to end.
